boardgame.name: BattleLore
戰爭之道
boardgame.description: This game is based upon Richard Borg's Command and Colors system. The world of BattleLore meshes history and fantasy together - putting players in command of an array of miniature troops on the battlefields of a Medieval Europe Uchronia at the outset of the Hundred Years War._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Drawing on the strengths of Memoir '44, this Days of Wonder game takes the time-tested Command and Colors system to a new level and offers gamers of many backgrounds a chance to fight medieval battles with a dose of epic fantasy._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;In this fantastical re-imagining of the Hundred Years War, French and English armies are supplemented with Goblins and Dwarves mercenaries and even some creatures like the Giant Spider and the Earth Elemental! Just as important as the armies you have, though, are the Lore Masters you choose to aid you: Wizards, Clerics, Warriors and Rogues can all aid you with unique powers and spells in ways role-playing gamers will find familiar._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;

Days of Wonder (DOW 7601) BattleLore Epic Fantasy Adventures Dawn breaks cold and damp on the edge of a European forest as old as history itself. Last night, your scouts stumbled upon the remains of a hastily departed Goblin camp. Sure enough, this morning their Crescent banners are silhouetted companies of noblemen on their war mounts. Will the forthcoming battle unfold as planned? Are your vaunted Dwarven mercenaries worth their costly wages? If you’ve chosen wisely, your place in history seems assured. If not…surely your heirs will pay the ransom…won’t they? 2 Players or Teams Age 10+ 60 minutes Content The Player’s Guide to BattleLore An Adventures Booklet Over 210 highly detailed miniatures. 58 Banner bearers and 15 extra banners. A double-sided battle map. 46 Terrain and Landmark tiles. A 60 Card Command Deck A 60 Card Lore Deck 42 Summary Cards 2 War Council Sheets 24 Lore Master Tokens 12 Battle Dice Online Access Number

Fantasy Flight Games (FFG BL01) Designed by Richard Borg, BattleLore is a briskly paced game for 2-4 players. The time is the Hundred Years War. All of Europe is engulfed in the flames of battle. Armies of French and English troops lined up alongside Goblin and Dwarven mercenaries. Mounted knights ride down on archers firing arrow after arrow to slow the advance. War Councils, armed with the power of Lore, cast spells of horrifying might. Will you take up a banner and march to war?

This is for a well played copy of the base game plus Call to Arms and Epic Battlelore expansion that I acquired from my local gaming club as it downsized its library. The box is missing the storage insert. The box has considerable shelf and edgewear and there is some splitting along the edges and corners of the box. These corners can easily be reinforced and the box can remain quite functional. The game is signed by Richard Borg and dated 7/6/07 which I know is authentic. The game is complete except for the following: Missing the 24 page adventure book (which is available for download on the Fantasy Flight website for downloading); the game is missing four banners--1 red standard swords 2 blue standard swordsman banners, and one green archer pennant; missing 3 heavy infantry figures (of 16); missing one medium cavalry; and is missing two human archers. The game has three extra regular infantry figures and 1 extra goblin skirmisher. While the game is incomplete, there are going to be few, if any, circumstances where the missing materials matter and most all parts are easily proxied with other figures or banners. 2006 Days of Wonder English edition. Fairly well played. The box shows moderate wear, but the components are all in very good condition. The biggest thing to consider is the previous owner single-color painted the otherwise gray miniatures in red, blue, green to more easily identify the unit strengths on the board. To differentiate the armies, he used solid colors for one and a silvery gloss (for lack of a better term, as I am not an expert on painting minis) for the other. You might still need to use the unit flags when you play, but perhaps not. Personally, I liked the effect.
